metadata.notes: Delivered shortly after the 1996 Centennial Olympic Park bombing.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher avoids 'must' and 'should' language. Instead of judging the woman who avoided the widow, he notes she had the 'grace to be ashamed,' inviting the listener to self-reflect rather than feel condemned.
quotes: I don’t dwell on it, but I can’t say I think as highly of them as I did before.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is present through empathy for real-world suffering (illness, bereavement) without offering 'cheap' comfort or creating dependency.
quotes: Real marriage is based on a long-term willingness to suffer the loss of illusion and build a lasting relationship based on reality.

adult.analysis: The sermon is heavily grounded in the Adult ego state. It uses linguistic analysis (dictionaries), historical context (Atlanta bombing), and psychological reality to process the 'here-and-now'. It explicitly rejects 'religious fantasy' in favor of 'flesh-and-blood' reality.
quotes: The definition in Webster’s Second Unabridged Dictionary doesn’t even come close.
The Christian path is not a self-indulgent flight into a world of angels and spirits and religious fantasy.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher does not use fear to gain compliance. He admits his own past 'grandiose' misunderstandings, modeling a Free Child's vulnerability rather than an Adapted Child's need to be 'right'.
quotes: I used to have a rather grandiose idea of suffering.

free_child_FC.analysis: Authentic joy and humor are present, specifically in the 'Bridge of Sighs' anecdote and the description of long-married women's humor. This is 'Free Child' energy used to process pain.
quotes: There really are few things more predictably funny than long-married women talking about their husbands.
The residents of the community call it... the Bridge of Sighs. This is wonderful. It is both funny and sad.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher treats the congregation as peers capable of handling complex truths (e.g., that things do NOT always work out for the best). It is an invitation to shared reality.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: None detected. The preacher is transparent about his own feelings and the limitations of the text.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The only slight risk of an ulterior transaction is the 'Social' Adult discussion of the bombing potentially masking a 'Psychological' Parent-Child push for civic unity, but the preacher keeps this grounded in the Adult by citing specific journalists and quotes.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The preacher avoids 'ITHY' (I'm Only Trying to Help You) by refusing to offer simplistic solutions. He avoids 'Ain't It Awful' by moving from the tragedy of the bombing to the 'Adult' agency of the grandmothers and Andrew Young. He explicitly deconstructs the 'Bait & Switch' of prosperity gospel by asserting that 'things don't necessarily work out for the best.'

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low. He provides tools for thought but does not claim to save the listener.
preacher_roles.persecutor: None. He avoids blaming the listener for their 'denial,' framing it instead as a common human struggle.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. He shares personal pain (his daughter's tumor) not to elicit pity, but to establish Adult credibility/empathy.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is invited into the role of 'Observer/Actor' rather than Victim. They are empowered to make small, real-world choices (calling a friend, asking for forgiveness).
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon offers a clear escape through 'Autonomy'—the move from denial (Victim) to reality (Adult).

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is an exceptional example of psychologically healthy homiletics. It operates primarily from the Adult ego state, inviting the listener into a reality-based faith rather than a regressive, Parent-Child dependency. By defining 'denial' as a theological and psychological hurdle, the preacher promotes autonomy and personal responsibility. He successfully navigates a national tragedy without falling into the 'Ain't It Awful' game, instead highlighting Adult agency and Free Child resilience (humor).
strengths: High Adult presence and intellectual honesty.
Use of humor (Free Child) to process suffering.
areas_for_improvement: The transition to the Andrew Young section relies heavily on external reporting, which briefly shifts the energy from personal Adult reflection to a more 'Nurturing Parent' civic narrative.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue to model vulnerability and the 'Adult' processing of scripture. The distinction between 'All things work for good' and 'God works for good' is a vital Adult intervention that prevents the 'Bait & Switch' game common in many pulpits.
